Ai.note: A Canaanite city near Bethel destroyed by Joshua (Joshua 7–8).

Ar.note: An ancient city of Moab located near the Arnon River (Numbers 21:28).

Ara.note: A city of the tribe of Asher mentioned in Joshua 19:30.

Arab.note: A town in Judah located in the hill country (Joshua 15:52).

Abilene.note: A district near Damascus ruled by Lysanias (Luke 3:1).

Accad.note: One of the cities in Nimrod’s kingdom in Shinar (Genesis 10:10).

Accho.note: A coastal city assigned to the tribe of Asher (Judges 1:31).

Aceldama.note: The 'Field of Blood' bought with Judas’s betrayal money (Acts 1:19).

Achaia.note: A Roman province in Greece visited by Paul (Acts 18:12).

Achmetha.note: Another name for Ecbatana, a Median capital (Ezra 6:2).

Achor.note: Valley where Achan was stoned for sin; symbol of trouble (Joshua 7:24–26).

Achshaph.note: A city in Canaan conquered by Joshua (Joshua 11:1).

Achzib.note: A town in Asher that the Israelites failed to conquer (Judges 1:31).

Adadah.note: A city in southern Judah listed among tribal allotments (Joshua 15:22).

Adami.note: A place near the territory of Naphtali (Joshua 19:33).

Adithaim.note: A city in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:36).

Admah.note: One of the cities destroyed with Sodom and Gomorrah (Genesis 10:19).

Adoraim.note: A fortified city of Judah built by Rehoboam (2 Chronicles 11:9).

Adramyttium.note: A port city in Asia Minor; Paul's ship originated from here (Acts 27:2).

Adullam.note: A cave near Judah where David hid from Saul (1 Samuel 22:1).

Adummim.note: A pass on the road from Jerusalem to Jericho (Joshua 15:7).

Ahava.note: The river where Ezra camped before returning to Jerusalem (Ezra 8:15).

Ahlab.note: A city in Asher not fully conquered by Israel (Judges 1:31).

Aiath.note: A city near Jerusalem mentioned in Isaiah's prophecy (Isaiah 10:28).

Ain.note: A city on the border of Judah and Benjamin (Joshua 15:32).

Ajalon.note: Valley where the sun stood still during Joshua’s battle (Joshua 10:12).

Akrabbim.note: A pass marking Judah’s southern border (Numbers 34:4).

Alammelech.note: A town in the tribal inheritance of Asher (Joshua 19:26).

Alemeth.note: A city of Benjamin listed among priestly towns (1 Chronicles 6:60).

Alush.note: An Israelite encampment during the wilderness journey (Numbers 33:13).

Amad.note: A town in the territory of Asher (Joshua 19:26).

Amana.note: A mountain mentioned in Song of Solomon as a symbol of beauty (Song 4:8).

Anab.note: A city in the hill country of Judah conquered by Joshua (Joshua 11:21).

Anaharath.note: A town in the territory of Issachar (Joshua 19:19).

Anathoth.note: A Levitical city in Benjamin and hometown of Jeremiah (Jeremiah 1:1).

Anem.note: A Levitical city in the territory of Issachar (1 Chronicles 6:73).

Anim.note: A city in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:50).

Antioch.note: A major city in Syria where followers of Jesus were first called Christians (Acts 11:26).

Antipatris.note: A city where Paul was taken by Roman soldiers en route to Caesarea (Acts 23:31).

Aphek.note: A site of battles between Israel and the Arameans or Philistines (1 Kings 20:26; 1 Samuel 4:1).

Apollonia.note: A city Paul passed through on his way to Thessalonica (Acts 17:1).

Arabia.note: A region visited by Paul after his conversion (Galatians 1:17).

Ararat.note: The mountains where Noah's ark came to rest after the flood (Genesis 8:4).

Areopagus.note: A hill in Athens where Paul delivered a sermon about the 'unknown god' (Acts 17:22).

Argob.note: A district in Bashan taken from Og by the Israelites (Deuteronomy 3:4).

Arimathea.note: Hometown of Joseph who buried Jesus’ body (Matthew 27:57).

Armageddon.note: The symbolic site of the final battle between good and evil (Revelation 16:16).

Arnon.note: A river marking the boundary of Moab (Numbers 21:13).

Aroer.note: A town near the Arnon River in the territory of Reuben (Deuteronomy 2:36).

Arpad.note: A Syrian city mentioned in Assyrian threats against Israel (2 Kings 18:34).

Arumah.note: A town near Shechem where Abimelech stayed (Judges 9:41).

Ashan.note: A city in the Negev assigned to the tribe of Judah (Joshua 15:42).

Ashdod.note: A Philistine city where the Ark of the Covenant was taken (1 Samuel 5:1).

Ashnah.note: A city in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:33).

Asia.note: A Roman province in western Asia Minor, frequently visited by Paul (Acts 19:10).

Askelon.note: A Philistine city judged by God's prophets (Zephaniah 2:4).

Aven.note: A place symbolizing idolatry, likely Heliopolis in Egypt (Ezekiel 30:17).

Avith.note: A city ruled by Hadad, king of Edom (Genesis 36:35).

Azekah.note: A city where the Amorites were defeated by Joshua (Joshua 10:10–11).

Azmon.note: A border town of southern Canaan (Numbers 34:4–5).

Azotus.note: Greek name for Ashdod, where Philip preached (Acts 8:40).

Baalah.note: Another name for Kirjath-jearim, where the Ark was kept (Joshua 15:9).

Baalath.note: A city built or fortified by Solomon (1 Kings 9:18).

Baale.note: Another name for Kirjath-jearim, where David brought the Ark (2 Samuel 6:2).

Babel.note: City where humanity built a tower and God confused their language (Genesis 11:9).

Babylon.note: Capital of the Babylonian empire and site of the Jewish exile located in ancient Mesopotamia. (2 Kings 24:15).

Baca.note: Valley symbolizing sorrow, turned to a place of springs by pilgrims (Psalm 84:6).

Bahurim.note: A village east of Jerusalem where Shimei cursed David (2 Samuel 16:5).

Bajith.note: A Moabite city mentioned in prophecy against Moab (Isaiah 15:2).

Bamah.note: A high place of idolatry rebuked by Ezekiel (Ezekiel 20:29).

Bashan.note: A fertile land east of the Jordan known for its strong oaks and cattle (Deuteronomy 3:10).

Beer.note: A desert oasis where the Lord told Moses to gather the people (Numbers 21:16).

Beeroth.note: A Gibeonite city whose people made a covenant with Israel (Joshua 9:17).

Bozrah.note: City in Edom, often symbolizing judgment and destruction.

Cabbon.note: A city in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:40).

Cabul.note: A region given by Solomon to Hiram of Tyre, who was displeased with it (1 Kings 9:13).

Calah.note: One of the cities built by Nimrod in Assyria (Genesis 10:11–12).

Calneh.note: One of Nimrod’s early cities in Shinar (Genesis 10:10).

Calno.note: A city conquered by Assyria, compared with Jerusalem (Isaiah 10:9).

Calvary.note: The place outside Jerusalem where Jesus was crucified (Luke 23:33).

Camon.note: A town east of the Jordan where Jair was buried (Judges 10:5).

Cana.note: A town in Galilee where Jesus performed His first miracle (John 2:1).

Capernaum.note: A city by the Sea of Galilee, center of Jesus’ ministry (Matthew 4:13).

Caphtor.note: Land of origin of the Philistines, often identified with Crete (Amos 9:7).

Cappadocia.note: A region in Asia Minor with Jewish converts at Pentecost (Acts 2:9).

Casiphia.note: A place near Babylon where Ezra gathered Levites for the return (Ezra 8:17).

Cedron.note: Also called Kidron; a valley near Jerusalem crossed by Jesus (John 18:1).

Cenchrea.note: A port of Corinth where Phoebe served the church (Romans 16:1).

Chaldea.note: Region of southern Babylon, home of Abraham (Genesis 11:28).

Charran.note: Also called Haran, where Abraham stayed after leaving Ur (Genesis 11:31).

Chebar.note: A river in Babylon where Ezekiel saw visions (Ezekiel 1:1).

Chephirah.note: One of the Gibeonite cities that made peace with Israel (Joshua 9:17).

Cherith.note: A brook east of Jordan where Elijah was fed by ravens (1 Kings 17:3).

Chesil.note: A city in the south of Judah, possibly same as Bethul (Joshua 15:30).

Chesulloth.note: A town in the territory of Issachar (Joshua 19:18).

Chilmad.note: A place mentioned in the context of trade with Tyre (Ezekiel 27:23).

Chios.note: An island in the Aegean Sea visited during Paul’s third missionary journey (Acts 20:15).

Chorazin.note: A city rebuked by Jesus for its unbelief (Matthew 11:21).

Chozeba.note: A town in Judah, possibly connected to Shelah’s descendants (1 Chronicles 4:22).

Chun.note: A city from which David took bronze for the temple (1 Chronicles 18:8).

Cilicia.note: A Roman province in Asia Minor, Paul’s home region (Acts 21:39).

Clauda.note: A small island near Crete passed by Paul’s ship (Acts 27:16).

Cnidus.note: A port on the southwestern coast of Asia Minor passed by Paul (Acts 27:7).

Colosse.note: A city in Asia Minor addressed by Paul in his letter to the Colossians (Colossians 1:2).

Coos.note: An island Paul passed on his return journey to Jerusalem (Acts 21:1).

country.note: A general term for a region or area, often used in the context of biblical narratives.

Corinth.note: A major Greek city where Paul founded a church (Acts 18:1).

Crete.note: An island where Paul left Titus to organize the church (Titus 1:5).

Cuth.note: A land from which the Assyrians brought settlers to Samaria (2 Kings 17:24).

Cyprus.note: An island in the Mediterranean visited by Paul and Barnabas (Acts 13:4).

Cyrene.note: A North African city, home of Simon who carried Jesus' cross (Luke 23:26).

Dabareh.note: A Levitical city in the territory of Issachar (Joshua 21:28).

Dabbasheth.note: A town on the border of Zebulun (Joshua 19:11).

Daberath.note: A Levitical city in Issachar near Mount Tabor (Joshua 21:28).

Dalmanutha.note: A region Jesus visited after feeding the four thousand (Mark 8:10).

Dalmatia.note: A Roman province where Titus went for ministry (2 Timothy 4:10).

Damascus.note: Capital of Syria and site of Paul’s conversion (Acts 9:3).

Dannah.note: A town in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:49).

Dedan.note: An Arabian trading tribe mentioned in prophecy (Isaiah 21:13).

Diblath.note: A location mentioned in Ezekiel's prophecy against Moab (Ezekiel 6:14, possibly a textual variant of 'Diblah').

Dibon.note: A Moabite city captured by Israel and given to Reuben (Numbers 21:30; 32:3).

Dilean.note: A city in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:38).

Dimon.note: A Moabite town mentioned in judgment prophecy (Isaiah 15:9).

Dimonah.note: A town in the southern region of Judah (Joshua 15:22).

Dinhabah.note: Capital of King Bela of Edom (Genesis 36:32).

Dophkah.note: A wilderness station of the Israelites (Numbers 33:12).

Dor.note: A coastal Canaanite city allotted to Manasseh (Joshua 17:11).

Dothan.note: Where Joseph was sold by his brothers and Elisha saw heavenly armies (Genesis 37:17; 2 Kings 6:13–17).

Dura.note: The plain where Nebuchadnezzar set up his golden image (Daniel 3:1).

Ebronah.note: A wilderness encampment of the Israelites (Numbers 33:34).

Eden.note: The paradise garden where Adam and Eve lived before the fall (Genesis 2:8).

Eder.note: A place name mentioned in connection with the boundary of Judah (Joshua 15:21).

Edrei.note: A city in Bashan where Israel defeated King Og (Numbers 21:33).

Eglaim.note: A location mentioned in prophecy against Moab (Isaiah 15:8).

Elath.note: A port city on the Red Sea near Ezion-geber (2 Kings 14:22).

Elealeh.note: A Moabite town mentioned in prophetic judgments (Isaiah 15:4).

Eleph.note: A town in the territory of Benjamin (Joshua 18:28).

Ellasar.note: A kingdom allied with Chedorlaomer in the war of Genesis 14 (Genesis 14:1).

Eltekeh.note: A Levitical city in the territory of Dan (Joshua 21:23).

Eltolad.note: A town in the inheritance of Simeon (Joshua 19:4).

Emmaus.note: The village where the risen Jesus appeared to two disciples (Luke 24:13).

Enam.note: A city in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:34).

Enan.note: A northern boundary marker of the Promised Land (Numbers 34:9–10).

Ephesus.note: A major city where Paul ministered and wrote the letter to the Ephesians (Acts 19:1).

Ephratah.note: An older name for Bethlehem, the city of David (Micah 5:2).

Erech.note: A city in Nimrod’s kingdom in Shinar (Genesis 10:10).

Eshean.note: A town in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:52).

Eshtaol.note: A town where Samson began to be moved by the Spirit (Judges 13:25).

Eshtemoa.note: A Levitical city in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 21:14).

Ether.note: A town in the territory of Judah and Simeon (Joshua 15:42; 19:7).

Euphrates.note: A major river forming part of the Promised Land’s boundary (Genesis 15:18).

Ezel.note: A stone near Saul’s court where David and Jonathan met (1 Samuel 20:19).

Ezem.note: A town in the south of Judah and Simeon (Joshua 15:29; 19:3).

face of all the earth.note: A phrase used in Scripture to refer to the entire inhabited world (Genesis 1:28; Psalm 72:8).

face of the ground.note: A phrase used in Scripture to refer to the surface of the earth (Genesis 3:19; Genesis 4:14).

Gaash.note: The hill near which Joshua was buried (Judges 2:9).

Gabbatha.note: The stone pavement where Pilate judged Jesus (John 19:13).

Galatia.note: A Roman province in Asia Minor addressed by Paul in his epistle (Galatians 1:2).

Galilee.note: Region where Jesus began His ministry and performed many miracles (Matthew 4:23).

Gallim.note: A town in Benjamin mentioned during Saul’s story (1 Samuel 25:44).

Gath.note: A Philistine city and hometown of Goliath (1 Samuel 17:4).

Gaza.note: A Philistine city where Samson performed mighty acts (Judges 16:1–3).

Gazer.note: An alternate spelling of Gezer, a city captured by Pharaoh and given to Solomon (1 Kings 9:16).

Geba.note: A town of Benjamin assigned to the Levites (Joshua 21:17).

Gebal.note: A city in Phoenicia mentioned in Ezekiel’s prophecy (Ezekiel 27:9).

Gebim.note: A town near Jerusalem mentioned in Isaiah’s prophecy (Isaiah 10:31).

Geder.note: A city in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:58).

Gederothaim.note: A town in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:36).

Gennesaret.note: A fertile region and sea where Jesus taught and healed (Luke 5:1).

Gerar.note: A Philistine town where Abraham and Isaac sojourned (Genesis 20:1; 26:1).

Gergesenes.note: Region where Jesus cast demons into swine (Matthew 8:28).

Gerizim.note: Mount of blessing in Israel and later Samaritan worship (Deuteronomy 11:29; John 4:20).

Geshur.note: A kingdom northeast of Israel, home of Absalom’s mother (2 Samuel 3:3).

Gethsemane.note: The garden where Jesus prayed before His arrest (Matthew 26:36).

Gezer.note: A Canaanite city captured and fortified by Solomon (1 Kings 9:16–17).

Giah.note: A place near Gibeon associated with the pursuit of Abner by Joab (2 Samuel 2:24).

Gibbethon.note: A Levitical city in Dan where battles with the Philistines occurred (Joshua 21:23; 1 Kings 15:27).

Gibeah.note: Saul’s hometown and site of a civil war incident (Judges 19–20; 1 Samuel 10:26).

Gibeon.note: A city that made peace with Israel and hosted Solomon’s dream (Joshua 9:3; 1 Kings 3:5).

Gihon.note: A spring in Jerusalem where Solomon was anointed king (1 Kings 1:33).

Gilboa.note: Mountains where Saul and his sons died in battle (1 Samuel 31:1).

Gilgal.note: Israel’s first camp after crossing the Jordan River (Joshua 4:19).

Giloh.note: Ahithophel’s hometown in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:51; 2 Samuel 15:12).

Gimzo.note: A town taken by the Philistines in King Ahaz’s time (2 Chronicles 28:18).

Gittaim.note: A town resettled by Benjamites after the exile (Nehemiah 11:33).

Goath.note: A place near Jerusalem mentioned in Jeremiah’s prophecy (Jeremiah 31:39).

Gob.note: A site of battle between David’s men and the Philistines (2 Samuel 21:18–19).

Golan.note: A city of refuge in Bashan allotted to Manasseh (Deuteronomy 4:43).

Golgotha.note: The hill outside Jerusalem where Jesus was crucified (Matthew 27:33).

Gomorrah.note: A city destroyed by God for wickedness along with Sodom (Genesis 19:24–25).

Goshen.note: The region in Egypt where the Israelites lived (Genesis 47:6).

Gozan.note: A region in Assyria where Israelites were exiled (2 Kings 17:6).

Gudgodah.note: A station in Israel’s wilderness journey (Deuteronomy 10:7).

Gur.note: A place where Jehu struck down Ahaziah (2 Kings 9:27).

Habor.note: A river region in Assyria where exiled Israelites were settled (2 Kings 17:6).

Hachilah.note: A hill in the wilderness where David hid from Saul (1 Samuel 23:19).

Hadashah.note: A town in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:37).

Hadid.note: A town reoccupied by returning exiles (Ezra 2:33).

Hadrach.note: A region in Syria mentioned in prophetic judgment (Zechariah 9:1).

Halah.note: A region in Assyria where Israelites were exiled (2 Kings 17:6).

Halak.note: A mountain marking Israel’s southern conquest border (Joshua 11:17).

Halhul.note: A city in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:58).

Hali.note: A town in the inheritance of Asher (Joshua 19:25).

Hamath.note: A northern city often marking Israel’s border (2 Kings 14:25).

Hamonah.note: The name of a city near Gog’s burial site (Ezekiel 39:16).

Hanes.note: An Egyptian city criticized in prophecy (Isaiah 30:4).

Hannathon.note: A town on the border of Zebulun (Joshua 19:14).

Hara.note: A region in Mesopotamia where Israelites were exiled (1 Chronicles 5:26).

Haradah.note: A stop in Israel’s wilderness journey (Numbers 33:24).

Harod.note: A spring near Gideon’s army camp (Judges 7:1).

Harosheth.note: Home of Sisera, commander of Jabin’s army (Judges 4:2).

Hauran.note: A region of Bashan mentioned in prophecy (Ezekiel 47:16).

Hazeroth.note: A wilderness station where Miriam and Aaron opposed Moses (Numbers 12:1).

heaven.note: A term often used in Scripture to refer to the sky or the dwelling place of God (Genesis 1:1; Psalm 115:16).

Hebron.note: Abraham settled here and David reigned from it (Genesis 13:18; 2 Samuel 2:11).

Helam.note: Site of a battle between David’s army and Arameans (2 Samuel 10:16–17).

Helbah.note: A city in Asher not fully conquered by Israel (Judges 1:31).

Heleph.note: A town on the border of Naphtali (Joshua 19:33).

Hermon.note: A mountain marking Israel’s northern border and known for dew imagery (Psalm 133:3).

Heshbon.note: Capital of King Sihon, later possessed by Israel (Numbers 21:26).

Heshmon.note: A city in the south of Judah (Joshua 15:27).

Hethlon.note: A landmark on Israel’s northern boundary in Ezekiel’s vision (Ezekiel 47:15).

Hiddekel.note: One of the four rivers of Eden, often identified with the Tigris (Genesis 2:14).

Hierapolis.note: A city near Colossae and Laodicea mentioned in Paul's letter (Colossians 4:13).

Hilen.note: A Levitical city in Judah (1 Chronicles 6:58).

Hinnom.note: A valley south of Jerusalem associated with child sacrifice and later symbolic of judgment (Jeremiah 7:31).

Hobah.note: A place north of Damascus where Abram pursued Lot’s captors (Genesis 14:15).

Horeb.note: The mountain where Moses received the Ten Commandments (Exodus 3:1; Deuteronomy 5:2).

Hormah.note: A city defeated by Israel in the wilderness (Numbers 21:3).

Horonaim.note: A Moabite city mentioned in judgment oracles (Isaiah 15:5).

Ibleam.note: A city in Manasseh where Ahaziah was wounded (2 Kings 9:27).

Iconium.note: A city visited by Paul and Barnabas on their missionary journey (Acts 14:1).

Idumea.note: Greek name for Edom, often hostile to Israel (Mark 3:8).

Iim.note: A town in the south of Judah (Joshua 15:29).

Ijon.note: A northern city captured by the kings of Syria and Assyria (1 Kings 15:20).

Illyricum.note: A Roman province where Paul preached the gospel (Romans 15:19).

India.note: Eastern extent of King Ahasuerus’s empire (Esther 1:1).

Iturea.note: A region ruled by Herod Philip, mentioned in the Gospels (Luke 3:1).

Ivah.note: A city defeated by Assyria, mentioned in their boasting (2 Kings 18:34).

Jabbok.note: A river where Jacob wrestled with a divine being (Genesis 32:22).

Jabneel.note: A border town of Judah, possibly same as later Jamnia (Joshua 15:11).

Jagur.note: A town in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:21).

Jahaz.note: The place where Israel defeated King Sihon (Numbers 21:23).

Jeshimon.note: A wilderness near the Dead Sea (1 Samuel 23:19).

Jokim.note: A descendant of Shelah, from the tribe of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:22).

Joppa.note: A port city where Jonah fled and Peter saw a vision (Jonah 1:3; Acts 10:9).

Jordan.note: The river that Israel crossed into Canaan and where Jesus was baptized (Joshua 3:17; Matthew 3:13).

Juttah.note: A priestly city in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 21:16).

Kabzeel.note: A city in southern Judah, home of Benaiah (2 Samuel 23:20).

Kadesh.note: A major wilderness encampment where Miriam died and Moses struck the rock (Numbers 20:1–11).

Kanah.note: A boundary stream between Ephraim and Manasseh (Joshua 17:9).

Karkaa.note: A town on the southern border of Judah (Joshua 15:3).

Karkor.note: A place where Gideon pursued the Midianite kings (Judges 8:10).

Karnaim.note: A city in Bashan captured by the Assyrians (Amos 6:13).

Kedemoth.note: A wilderness near Moab, granted to the Levites (Deuteronomy 2:26; Joshua 21:37).

Kerioth.note: A Moabite city named in prophetic judgment (Jeremiah 48:24).

Keziz.note: A city in the territory of Benjamin (Joshua 18:21).

Kidron.note: A valley east of Jerusalem, crossed by Jesus on the way to Gethsemane (John 18:1).

Kinah.note: A town in the Negev allotted to Judah (Joshua 15:22).

Kir.note: A region in Assyria where exiles from Damascus were taken (2 Kings 16:9).

Kishon.note: A river where Sisera’s army was swept away (Judges 5:21).

Kithlish.note: A town in the territory of Judah (Joshua 15:40).

Kitron.note: A town in Zebulun not fully conquered by Israel (Judges 1:30).

Kittim.note: Refers to Cyprus or western maritime lands (Isaiah 23:1).

Koa.note: A people or region mentioned in Ezekiel’s prophecy of judgment (Ezekiel 23:23).

Lachish.note: A fortified city of Judah conquered by Assyria (2 Kings 18:14).

Lahmam.note: A town in the Shephelah region of Judah (Joshua 15:40).

Laish.note: A city in the north taken and renamed Dan by the tribe of Dan (Judges 18:29).

Laodicea.note: A city addressed in Revelation for its lukewarm faith (Revelation 3:14–16).

Lasea.note: A city near Fair Havens on the island of Crete (Acts 27:8).

Lebaoth.note: A town in the Negev of Judah (Joshua 15:32).

Lasha.note: A city marking the boundary of the Canaanites (Genesis 10:19).

Lebanon.note: Mountainous region north of Israel known for its cedars; mentioned in many biblical contexts (1 Kings 5:6).

Leshem.note: A city captured and renamed Dan by the tribe of Dan (Joshua 19:47).

Libnah.note: A Levitical city in Judah that revolted against Judah's kings (2 Kings 8:22).

Libya.note: Region in North Africa associated with Cyrenians (Acts 2:10).

Luz.note: Original name of Bethel before Jacob renamed it (Genesis 28:19).

Lycaonia.note: A region in Asia Minor where Paul preached (Acts 14:6).

Lydda.note: A town where Peter healed Aeneas (Acts 9:32–34).

Lystra.note: City where Paul healed a cripple and was later stoned (Acts 14:8–19).

Maarath.note: A town in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:59).

Macedonia.note: Region in northern Greece visited by Paul during his missionary journeys (Acts 16:9).

Machbenah.note: A town in Judah’s genealogy (1 Chronicles 2:49).

Machpelah.note: Cave bought by Abraham as a family burial site (Genesis 23:9).

Madmannah.note: A town in the southern part of Judah (Joshua 15:31).

Madon.note: A Canaanite city whose king opposed Joshua (Joshua 11:1).

Magdala.note: Hometown of Mary Magdalene, located near the Sea of Galilee (Matthew 15:39).

Mahaz.note: A place where King Pekahiah was assassinated (2 Kings 15:30, possibly a variant reading).

Makheloth.note: An Israelite encampment in the wilderness (Numbers 33:25).

Makkedah.note: A city where Joshua trapped five Amorite kings (Joshua 10:10–28).

Mamre.note: An oak grove near Hebron where Abraham lived (Genesis 13:18).

Maon.note: A wilderness where David hid from Saul (1 Samuel 23:24).

Maralah.note: A town on the border of Zebulun (Joshua 19:11).

Maroth.note: A town mentioned in lament for Jerusalem (Micah 1:12).

Meah.note: A tower in the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 3:1).

Mearah.note: A place near Sidon listed in the unconquered territories (Joshua 13:4).

Mecherath.note: A town in Judah associated with Elhanan, one of David’s mighty men (2 Samuel 23:34).

Medeba.note: A Moabite city mentioned in Israel’s conquest (Numbers 21:30).

Media.note: A region in Persia mentioned during the exile (Esther 1:3).

Megiddo.note: A fortified city known for battles, including prophesied Armageddon (Revelation 16:16).

Megiddon.note: Alternate name for Megiddo in prophecy (Zechariah 12:11).

Mekonah.note: A town near Jerusalem listed among returnees from exile (Nehemiah 11:28).

Melita.note: Island where Paul was shipwrecked, identified as modern Malta (Acts 28:1).

Memphis.note: A major Egyptian city condemned by prophets (Jeremiah 46:19).

Meonenim.note: A plain near Shechem, associated with divination (Judges 9:37).

Mephaath.note: A Levitical city in Reuben’s territory (Joshua 13:18; 21:37).

Meribah.note: Where Moses struck the rock and was denied entry to Canaan (Numbers 20:13).

Merom.note: A lake and battle site where Joshua defeated Canaanite kings (Joshua 11:5).

Meronothite.note: A designation for people from Meronoth, likely near Gibeon (Nehemiah 3:7).

Meroz.note: A town cursed by Deborah for not helping in battle (Judges 5:23).

Mesobaite.note: A region associated with Jeiel, a Levite gatekeeper (1 Chronicles 26:25).

Mesopotamia.note: Region between the Tigris and Euphrates where Abraham originated (Genesis 24:10).

Michmethah.note: A landmark on the borders of Ephraim and Manasseh (Joshua 17:7).

Middin.note: A town in the wilderness of Judah (Joshua 15:61).

Migdol.note: A fortress town near the Red Sea where Israel encamped (Exodus 14:2).

Migron.note: A town near Gibeah where Saul camped (1 Samuel 14:2).

Misgab.note: A city in Moab mentioned in prophecy (Jeremiah 48:1).

Mishal.note: A town in Asher given to the Levites (Joshua 21:30).

Miletum.note: Where Paul left Trophimus sick (2 Timothy 4:20).

Millo.note: A structure or fortress in Jerusalem repaired by Solomon (1 Kings 11:27).

Minni.note: A people or region mentioned in Jeremiah’s prophecy against Babylon (Jeremiah 51:27).

Minnith.note: An Ammonite city noted for wheat trade (Ezekiel 27:17).

Misheal.note: A town in Asher allotted to the Levites (Joshua 21:30).

Mitylene.note: An island city visited by Paul during his journey (Acts 20:14).

Mizar.note: A little-known mountain mentioned in a psalm of longing (Psalm 42:6).

Mizpah.note: A town in Benjamin where Samuel judged Israel (1 Samuel 7:5–6).

Moreh.note: A hill near Shechem where Abraham built an altar (Genesis 12:6).

Moriah.note: Mountain where Abraham was to sacrifice Isaac and later site of Solomon’s temple (Genesis 22:2; 2 Chronicles 3:1).

Myra.note: A city in Lycia where Paul changed ships en route to Rome (Acts 27:5).

Mysia.note: A region in Asia Minor bypassed by Paul in his travels (Acts 16:7).

Nahaliel.note: A place where Israel camped in the wilderness (Numbers 21:19).

Nahallal.note: A town in Zebulun given to the Levites (Joshua 21:35).

Nain.note: Village where Jesus raised a widow’s son (Luke 7:11–15).

Naioth.note: A place in Ramah where Samuel and prophets gathered (1 Samuel 19:18).

Neapolis.note: A port in Macedonia where Paul landed (Acts 16:11).

Neballat.note: A town repopulated after the exile (Nehemiah 11:34).

Nebo.note: Mountain where Moses viewed the Promised Land before his death (Deuteronomy 34:1).

Nehelamite.note: A designation for Shemaiah, possibly referencing a location or people (Jeremiah 29:24).

Neiel.note: A town on the boundary of Asher (Joshua 19:27).

Nephish.note: A town in the territory of Simeon (1 Chronicles 4:42).

Nephishesim.note: A family or settlement of temple servants returning from exile (Ezra 2:50).

Nephthalim.note: Alternate spelling of Naphtali, a tribal territory in northern Israel (Matthew 4:13).

Nephusim.note: A family of temple servants returning from exile (Ezra 2:50).

Neziah.note: A family of temple servants listed among returnees from exile (Ezra 2:54).

Nezib.note: A town in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:43).

Nibshan.note: A city in the wilderness of Judah (Joshua 15:62).

Nicopolis.note: A city where Paul intended to spend the winter (Titus 3:12).

Nimrah.note: A city east of the Jordan, requested by the tribes of Reuben and Gad (Numbers 32:3).

Nineveh.note: Capital of Assyria, famously visited by Jonah (Jonah 3:3).

Nob.note: A priestly city where Saul ordered a massacre (1 Samuel 22:19).

Nod.note: The land east of Eden where Cain settled (Genesis 4:16).

Noph.note: An Egyptian city, also known as Memphis, condemned by prophets (Jeremiah 2:16).

Nophah.note: A town in Moab mentioned in poetic victory language (Numbers 21:30).

Oboth.note: An Israelite encampment during the wilderness journey (Numbers 21:10).

Ono.note: A town where Nehemiah was invited to a deceptive meeting (Nehemiah 6:2).

Ophel.note: A fortified area of Jerusalem mentioned in rebuilding accounts (2 Chronicles 27:3; Nehemiah 3:26).

Ophir.note: A region famous for its gold, visited by Solomon’s fleet (1 Kings 10:11).

Ophrah.note: A town in Manasseh where Gideon lived (Judges 6:11).

Pai.note: A city from which David took spoil; likely same as 'Tibhath' (1 Chronicles 18:8).

Palestina.note: A poetic term for Philistia used in prophecy (Exodus 15:14).

Pamphylia.note: A Roman province in Asia Minor visited by Paul (Acts 13:13).

Paphos.note: A city in Cyprus where Paul confronted Elymas the sorcerer (Acts 13:6).

Parah.note: A village in the territory of Benjamin (Joshua 18:23).

Paran.note: A wilderness region where Israel camped and Ishmael lived (Genesis 21:21; Numbers 10:12).

Parbar.note: A temple-related area assigned to gatekeepers (1 Chronicles 26:18).

Patara.note: A port city in Lycia visited by Paul (Acts 21:1).

Pathros.note: A region of Upper Egypt referenced in prophecy (Isaiah 11:11).

Patmos.note: The island where John received the Revelation (Revelation 1:9).

Pau.note: A city of Edom, home of King Hadar (Genesis 36:39).

Pekod.note: A Chaldean tribe mentioned in judgment prophecy (Jeremiah 50:21).

Peor.note: A mountain associated with Baal worship and Israel’s sin (Numbers 25:3).

Perazim.note: Site where the Lord broke out like waters against enemies (Isaiah 28:21).

Perga.note: A city in Pamphylia where Paul preached (Acts 13:13–14).

Pergamos.note: One of the seven churches addressed in Revelation (Revelation 2:12).

Pharpar.note: A river of Damascus mentioned by Naaman (2 Kings 5:12).

Phenice.note: A port on Crete where Paul hoped to winter before his shipwreck (Acts 27:12).

Philadelphia.note: One of the seven churches addressed in Revelation, commended for faithfulness (Revelation 3:7).

Philippi.note: A Macedonian city where Paul was imprisoned and converted Lydia (Acts 16:12).

Phrygia.note: A region in Asia Minor mentioned in Pentecost and Paul’s journeys (Acts 2:10; 16:6).

Pirathon.note: A town in Ephraim, home of Judge Abdon (Judges 12:15).

Pisgah.note: A mountain range where Moses viewed the Promised Land (Deuteronomy 34:1).

Pisidia.note: A region in Asia Minor where Paul preached at Antioch (Acts 13:14).

Pison.note: One of the four rivers of Eden, flowing around Havilah (Genesis 2:11).

Pithom.note: A store city built by the Israelites in Egypt (Exodus 1:11).

Pontus.note: A region in Asia Minor, home of Aquila (Acts 18:2).

Punon.note: A station during Israel’s wilderness journey (Numbers 33:42).

Puteoli.note: Italian port where Paul landed before reaching Rome (Acts 28:13).

Rabbah.note: Capital of Ammon, captured by David (2 Samuel 12:26).

Rachal.note: A town in Judah mentioned in David’s gifts (1 Samuel 30:29).

Rakkath.note: A town in Naphtali, possibly later called Tiberias (Joshua 19:35).

Rakkon.note: A town near Joppa in Dan’s territory (Joshua 19:46).

Ramah.note: A town in Benjamin associated with the prophet Samuel (1 Samuel 7:17).

Ramath.note: A shortened form of several towns, such as Ramath-lehi or Ramathaim-zophim.

Rehob.note: A city in Asher’s territory, not fully conquered (Judges 1:31).

Rehoboth.note: A well dug by Isaac meaning 'broad places' (Genesis 26:22).

Rephidim.note: A wilderness station where Israel battled Amalek (Exodus 17:1–8).

Resen.note: A city built by Asshur between Nineveh and Calah (Genesis 10:12).

Rezeph.note: A city claimed by the king of Assyria as conquered (2 Kings 19:12).

Rhegium.note: A port in southern Italy visited by Paul on his voyage to Rome (Acts 28:13).

Rhodes.note: An island Paul passed on his way to Jerusalem (Acts 21:1).

Riblah.note: A Syrian town where Judah’s king was judged and punished (2 Kings 25:6).

Rimmon.note: A town in Benjamin where men of Gibeah fled (Judges 20:47).

Rissah.note: A campsite in Israel’s wilderness journey (Numbers 33:21).

Rithmah.note: Another station during the wilderness wanderings (Numbers 33:18).

Rogelim.note: Home of Barzillai the Gileadite who aided David (2 Samuel 17:27).

Rome.note: Capital of the Roman Empire and location of Paul’s imprisonment (Acts 28:16).

Rosh.note: A nation or region in Ezekiel’s prophecy, sometimes interpreted as Russia (Ezekiel 38:2).

Mizpeh.note: Alternate spelling of Mizpah, referring to the same regions (Joshua 11:3).

Moladah.note: A town in the territory of Judah (Joshua 15:26).

Rumah.note: A city mentioned as the home of Pedaiah, father of Zebidah (2 Kings 23:36).

Salamis.note: A city on Cyprus where Paul and Barnabas preached (Acts 13:5).

Salcah.note: A city in Bashan allotted to the tribe of Gad (Deuteronomy 3:10).

Salem.note: The city of Melchizedek, king and priest of God Most High (Genesis 14:18).

Salim.note: A place near Aenon where John was baptizing (John 3:23).

Samaria.note: Capital of the northern kingdom of Israel (1 Kings 16:24).

Samos.note: An island near which Paul sailed during his third missionary journey (Acts 20:15).

Samothracia.note: An island where Paul stopped en route to Philippi (Acts 16:11).

Sansannah.note: A city in the Negev of Judah (Joshua 15:31).

Sardis.note: One of the seven churches addressed in Revelation (Revelation 3:1).

Sarepta.note: A Phoenician town where Elijah stayed with a widow (1 Kings 17:9; Luke 4:26).

Sarid.note: A town marking Zebulun’s southern border (Joshua 19:10).

Saron.note: A fertile plain in Israel known for beauty (Isaiah 35:2; Acts 9:35).

Sephar.note: A place mentioned in the genealogy of the Edomites (Genesis 36:23).

Sepharvaim.note: A city in the territory of the tribe of Ephraim (Joshua 18:24).

Shaalbim.note: A town in Dan’s territory that remained unconquered (Judges 1:35).

Shaalbonite.note: A person from Shaalbim, home of one of David’s mighty men (2 Samuel 23:32).

Shaveh.note: The valley where Melchizedek met Abram (Genesis 14:17).

Shechem.note: A significant city in Israel’s history, site of Jacob’s well (Genesis 33:18).

Shibmah.note: A Moabite city known for vineyards (Numbers 32:38; Isaiah 16:9).

Shinar.note: The land where Babel and later Babylon was located (Genesis 11:2).

Shochoh.note: A town where the Philistines gathered before Goliath’s challenge (1 Samuel 17:1).

Shur.note: A desert near Egypt that Hagar passed through (Genesis 16:7).

Siddim.note: A valley near the Dead Sea where kings battled and tar pits were found (Genesis 14:3,10).

Sidon.note: A major Phoenician port city, often in contact with Israel (Judges 10:6; Acts 12:20).

Smyrna.note: One of the seven churches in Revelation, praised for endurance (Revelation 2:8).

Socoh.note: A town in Judah near Shochoh (1 Samuel 17:1).

Sodom.note: A wicked city destroyed by fire from heaven (Genesis 19:24).

Spain.note: Paul expressed desire to preach there (Romans 15:24).

Succoth.note: Israel’s first encampment after leaving Egypt (Exodus 12:37).

Sychar.note: Town in Samaria where Jesus spoke with the woman at the well (John 4:5).

Syene.note: A city in Egypt referenced in prophetic judgments (Ezekiel 30:6).

Syracuse.note: A city in Sicily where Paul stopped during his voyage (Acts 28:12).

Taanach.note: A Canaanite city near Megiddo given to the Levites (Joshua 21:25).

Tabbath.note: A town near the route of Gideon’s pursuit of Midianites (Judges 7:22).

Taberah.note: A wilderness encampment where fire from the Lord consumed complainers (Numbers 11:3).

Tabor.note: A prominent hill in Galilee, near where Deborah and Barak fought Sisera (Judges 4:6).

Tadmor.note: A city built by Solomon in the wilderness (2 Chronicles 8:4).

Tanach.note: Also spelled Taanach, a Levitical city in Issachar (Joshua 21:25).

Taralah.note: A town in the territory of Benjamin (Joshua 18:27).

Tarshish.note: Tarshish is placed on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea by several biblical passages, and more precisely: west of Israel. It is described as a source of various metals: 'beaten silver is brought from Tarshish' (Jeremiah 10:9), and the Phoenicians of Tyre brought from there silver, iron, tin and lead (Ezekiel 27:12).

Telah.note: Mentioned in the genealogy of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:25).

Telassar.note: A city ruled by the children of Eden, mentioned in Assyrian taunts (2 Kings 19:12).

Tema.note: A region in Arabia associated with the descendants of Ishmael (Job 6:19).

Teman.note: A city in Edom known for wisdom (Jeremiah 49:7).

Thebez.note: City where Abimelech died after a woman dropped a millstone on his head (Judges 9:50–53).

Thelasar.note: Alternate name of Telassar, cited in Assyrian conquests (Isaiah 37:12).

Thessalonica.note: A city in Macedonia where Paul preached and was opposed (Acts 17:1–9).

Thyatira.note: One of the seven churches in Revelation, known for its tolerance of false teaching (Revelation 2:18).

Tiberias.note: A city on the Sea of Galilee, mentioned in the Gospels (John 6:23).

Timnah.note: A Philistine town where Samson found a wife (Judges 14:1).

Timnath.note: A variant of Timnah; can also refer to Timnath-heres.

Tiphsah.note: A border city of Solomon’s kingdom (1 Kings 4:24).

Tirzah.note: A former capital of Israel before Samaria (1 Kings 14:17).

Tophel.note: A place near the wilderness mentioned in Moses’ summary speech (Deuteronomy 1:1).

Tophet.note: A valley in Jerusalem used for child sacrifice, condemned by prophets (Jeremiah 7:31).

Trachonitis.note: Region governed by Herod Philip during Jesus’ time (Luke 3:1).

Troas.note: A port city in Asia Minor where Paul had a vision of Macedonia (Acts 16:8–9).

Tyre.note: A major Phoenician port city condemned by several prophets (Ezekiel 26:7).

Ulai.note: A river near which Daniel saw a prophetic vision (Daniel 8:2).

Uphaz.note: A region known for fine gold (Jeremiah 10:9).

Ur.note: The Mesopotamian city where Abraham was born (Genesis 11:31).

Uzal.note: A descendant of Joktan and possibly a city in Arabia (Genesis 10:27).

Zaanannim.note: A site near Kedesh, associated with Heber’s tent (Judges 4:11).

Zair.note: A town near Edom attacked by King Jehoram (2 Kings 8:21).

Zalmonah.note: A camp during Israel’s wilderness journey (Numbers 33:41).

Zanoah.note: A town in Judah, later resettled after the exile (Nehemiah 3:13).

Zared.note: A brook marking the border of Moab (Numbers 21:12).

Zarephath.note: A Phoenician town where Elijah stayed with a widow (1 Kings 17:9).

Zaretan.note: A city near the Jordan River mentioned during the crossing (Joshua 3:16).

Zeboiim.note: One of the cities destroyed with Sodom and Gomorrah (Genesis 14:2).

Zedad.note: A northern boundary point of Israel (Numbers 34:8).

Zelah.note: A town in Benjamin where Saul and his family were buried (2 Samuel 21:14).

Zelzah.note: A place near Rachel’s tomb where Saul met a sign from Samuel (1 Samuel 10:2).

Zemaraim.note: A city in Benjamin and the site of a prophetic address (2 Chronicles 13:4).

Zenan.note: A town in the lowland of Judah (Joshua 15:37).

Zephath.note: A Canaanite city destroyed and renamed Hormah by the Israelites (Judges 1:17).

Ziddim.note: A town in the territory of Naphtali (Joshua 19:35).

Zidon.note: Another name for Sidon, a major Phoenician city (Genesis 10:15).

Zif.note: A wilderness area where David hid from Saul (1 Samuel 23:14).

Ziklag.note: A town given to David where he stayed during his flight from Saul (1 Samuel 27:6).

Zin.note: A desert area through which Israel journeyed (Numbers 20:1).

Zion.note: A hill in Jerusalem symbolic of God's presence and the future kingdom (Psalm 2:6).

Zior.note: A town in the hill country of Judah (Joshua 15:54).

Ziph.note: A Judahite town whose residents reported David to Saul (1 Samuel 23:19).

Ziphron.note: A northern border city of Israel (Numbers 34:9).

Ziz.note: A place in the wilderness near the Dead Sea (2 Chronicles 20:2).

Zoan.note: An ancient Egyptian city used in prophetic rebukes (Isaiah 19:11).

Zoar.note: A small town spared during the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah (Genesis 19:22).

Zobah.note: A Syrian kingdom conquered by Saul and David (1 Samuel 14:47).

Zophim.note: A high place in Moab where Balaam saw Israel (Numbers 23:14).

Peniel.note: The place where Jacob wrestled with God and was renamed Israel (Genesis 32:30).
